sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Afghanicenus nuristanicus ( Heyrovský, 1936 )
is hereby newly recorded from Pakistan based on a specimen collected at the beginning of the 20th century and preserved in the collection of the Natural History Museum , London. High quality colour images of the type material (a male syntype of
Purpuricenus nuristanicus
and a female syntype of
P. nuristanicus
f. bisignata ) are presented for the first time. Some literature information on the genus
Afghanicenus Heyrovský, 1941
is summarised, and taxonomic problems are highlighted and further discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Afghanicenus Heyrovský, 1941
is one of the most poorly studied cerambycid genera in the Palaearctic , even though it includes only three species:
Afghanicenus aulicus Holzschuh, 1981
,
Afghanicenus dreesi Tippmann, 1958
, and the type species
Afghanicenus nuristanicus ( Heyrovský, 1936 )
. The latter was originally described in the genus
Purpuricenus Dejean, 1821
(
). All three species are distributed exclusively in the territory of two South Asian countries: Afghanistan and Pakistan (
;
).
Afghanicenus aulicus
appears to be known only from a single female holotype collected in NW Pakistan (east of Kalam ) by Carolus Holzschuh in
May 1978
.
Afghanicenus dreesi
was described based on a series of five females , representing two colour forms (the nominal one and f. acutemaculata ), collected by Johann Friedrich Klapperich in
April and May 1953
; some of them, however, were collected in the same place and on the same day as typical individuals of
A . nuristanicus
. For both,
A . aulicus
and
A . dreesi
, there are no data on further specimens . Regarding
A . nuristanicus
, although more specimens are known in museum collections (some also in private collections), this species is still considered one of the greatest rarities among the Palaearctic Cerambycidae . Four different colour forms (the nominal one and f. reductesignata , f. bisignata , and f. rubripennis ) were already described in the original publication (
), which indicates a large variability of the elytral pattern.

This paper is not intended to formally revise the genus
Afghanicenus
but to summarise the available information, present some type specimens, and formally include
A . nuristanicus
in the fauna of Pakistan . Furthermore, it aims to highlight some potential taxonomic problems in this genus and the need for a thorough revision of all type material.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p:
The presented non-type specimen of
A . nuristanicus
is deposited in the collection of the Natural History Museum, London, UK—NHMUK (formerly British Museum, Natural History—BMNH). The other presented type specimens are housed in the collection of the Senckenberg Deutsches Entomologisches Institut , Müncheberg , Germany (SDEI).

The discussed specimen from Pakistan was examined using an Olympus SZH10 stereo microscope at 7–140× magnification and imaged with a Keyence VHX-7000 digital microscope, at the Museum and Institute of Zoology, Polish Academy of Sciences, Poland (MIZ). The obtained image was automatically stacked and combined using a Keyence VHX-7000 digital microscope. The colour plates were prepared using GIMP v. 2.10.10 (www.gimp.org). The distribution of the species was illustrated in Paint.NET (www.getpaint.net) using National Geographic World Map (
) as the raster layer.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
As a result of examination of the cerambycid specimens from Central Asia deposited in the NHMUK, an interesting, unidentified specimen of the tribe Trachyderini Dupont, 1836 was found, collected in Chitral , in northern Pakistan , in the early 20th Century. The specimen was subsequently identified as
Afghanicenus nuristanicus
, which constitutes the first record of this species from Pakistan . We present here the discussed specimen ( Figs 1C & 2C ) with its original label ( Fig. 3C ), as well as two syntypes (male and female) of
A. nuristanicus
( Figs 1A & 2A ) and
A. nuristanicus
f. bisignata ( Figs 1B & 2B ) and their labels ( Fig. 3A, B , respectively). The locality in Pakistan as well as the type locality of
A . nuristanicus
are marked in the map of the region ( Fig. 4 ).

The stacked colour images of the type material presented in this paper ( Figs 1A, B & 2A, B ) are of sufficient quality to be used to determine specimens of this species, including the NHMUK specimen ( Figs 1C & 2C ). The specimen from Pakistan is a female, therefore, due to the quite strong sexual dimorphism in this species, we presented here both, a male syntype of
A . nuristanicus
( Figs 1A & 2A ), and a female syntype of
A . nuristanicus
f. bisignata ( Figs 1B & 2B ). The studied specimen can be assigned to
A . nuristanicus
primarily based on the pronotal and elytral punctation. Our previous studies showed that these morphological traits were the most informative in the closely related genus
Anoplistes Audinet-Serville, 1833
(see more in the Discussion section), and according to the results of preliminary morphological analysis, they also seem to be diagnostic in
Afghanicenus
. The very different elytral pattern (shape and size of elytral spots) between the Pakistani specimen and the male syntype of the nominal colour form is taxonomically irrelevant as this character is highly variable in this species and in many representatives of the closely related genera. For instance,
A . nuristanicus
f. bisignata presented here ( Figs 1B & 2B ) has an almost identical elytral pattern (two small dots), while the other form (f. rubripennis ) is characterised by the absence of any spots on the elytra.

Distribution map ( Fig. 4 ) shows that the distance between the type locality of
A . nuristanicus
in Afghanistan and the city of Chitral in Pakistan is small (several dozen kilometres in a straight line), hence the occurrence of this species in the latter country is not surprising. It should be noted, however, that the exact type locality (Gulam-Tal, i.e. Gulam Valley) is not known to the authors with certainty, but it is surely located in Nuristan Province, most likely in its easternmost part. Our investigation determined with a high degree of confidence that the Gulam Valley is now the Bashgal Valley (also called the Landai Sin Valley). Additionally, the founder or governor of the Bashgal Valley was the Afghan prince Ghulam Haidar Khan, which only supports this connection.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Afghanicenus nuristanicus
was not illustrated in the original description (
; as
Purpuricenus nuristanicus
); male and female specimens were depicted for the first time only five years later, in the article establishing the genus
Afghanicenus ( Heyrovský 1941 : p. 36)
. However, the quality of these black and white photographs is far from sufficient to assess the morphological details. Therefore, the stacked colour images presented in this paper are intended to enable the identification of further specimens. The specimen presented from Chitral definitely belongs to
A. nuristanicus
, which means this is the first report of this species from the territory of Pakistan . The label ( Fig. 3C ) was printed by the BMNH and reads 'Chitral/ R. Hill/ 1910-13 ' with an orange coloured bar indicating 'Oriental Region' (which at that time was considered to include much of what we now treat as Palaearctic). The number 1910-13 is a serial registration number indicating the 13th acquisition to the BMNH collections in year 1910. This number was checked in the old BMNH Registers, handwritten leather-bound ledgers of acquisitions held at the Natural History Museum, and the record for 1910-13 refers to a collection of “17 insects, 7 Coleoptera , 8 Diptera and 2 Hymenoptera, from Chitral, presented by R. Hill Esq. on 11th January 1910 ”. Little could be found about R. Hill, although one of the Diptera he collected in Chitral at the same time was described by
as a new species of flower-fly,
Chrysotoxum fuscomarginatum
( Syrphidae ). It is likely that Hill was in Chitral in 1909 or earlier, and that he collected a few conspicuous insects while there (both the specimens we are aware of, the
Afghanicenus
and
Chrysotoxum ,
belong to genera that feed openly on flowers), but that Coleoptera were not his main interest. This is further supported by the fact that the
Afghanicenus
specimen was pinned through the pronotum, a style of pinning not typical among coleopterists then or now. The inclusion of an
Afghanicenus
in such a small, casual collection of just 17 specimens implies that the scarcity of the genus in collections around the world is because of a lack of collecting in the areas where it occurs, rather than its actual rarity.

The specimen from Chitral was identified as
A. nuristanicus
primarily based on the pronotal and elytral punctation, clearly visible in high resolution images; our previous studies on the closely related genus
Anoplistes
(
;
) proved that these morphological traits were the most informative, which is likely true also for other related genera of the tribe Trachyderini , e.g.
Purpuricenus
(own unpublished observations).

Afghanicenus aulicus
, described based on a single female specimen, was at that time the only known
Afghanicenus species
known to be distributed in Pakistan .
stated that
A . aulicus
differs from
A. nuristanicus
by a shiny head and pronotum as well as dull, flat elytra. However, the author admitted that he did not have an opportunity to study the holotype of the latter and that he knew it only from the original description. While all of this clearly indicates the need for detailed study of the holotype of
A . aulicus
to decide whether it is a valid taxon, based on the photograph of Holzschuh’s holotype , we tentatively consider it to be a valid species. There are some differences in the pronotal punctation, overall body pubescence, and the shape of the elytra, but at this stage it is not yet clear whether these differences are due to individual variability. The photograph itself is not of sufficiently good quality, while the holotype is preserved in Carolus Holzschuh’s private collection ( Villach , Austria ).

On the other hand,
described
Afghanicenus dreesi
claiming that this species differs from
A. nuristanicus
mainly by the lighter and more shiny elytra, longer pubescence of several body parts, different shape of the pronotal processes, and different elytral punctation. However,
A . dreesi
was described based on a series of five females and it is noteworthy that they were collected during the same expedition (in the same village, Bashgultal) and some of them on the same day and at the same altitude as typical individuals of
A . nuristanicus
. This may raise some doubts as to the validity of designating a new species. Nevertheless, based on the high resolution images and clearly visible different pronotal and elytral punctation as well as different shape of the pronotum and its processes, designating a new species seems justified. Yet, it cannot be ruled out that
A . aulicus
, described in 1981, is a junior synonym of
A . dreesi
, considering that some of the characters distinguishing these two species from
A. nuristanicus
(e.g. long pubescence and lighter, dull elytra) are the same, while Holzschuh did not refer to
A . dreesi
at all in his description.

Moreover, the genus
Afghanicenus
itself was established based on the differences in some characters, presented in the key to the closely related genera (e.g. pronotal spines and prosternal processes;
), which in fact are not relevant anymore. After description of certain species of
Anoplistes
and
Purpuricenus
, which were unknown in the year of description of
Afghanicenus
, and more importantly after the description of
Afghanicenus dreesi
, the key is no longer useful and, consequently, the differential diagnosis for the genus
Afghanicenus
seems to be inadequate. Therefore, this genus probably needs to be carefully redescribed, but also it should be investigated and discussed whether this taxon is monophyletic and if so, if it deserves its taxonomic status, or perhaps should be downgraded to a subgeneric level (for instance in the genus
Anoplistes
). Ideally, such a study would require measuring the COI genetic distance between some representatives of these genera, but this would most likely involve obtaining fresh individuals of
Afghanicenus
, which currently seems unlikely due to the region of their distribution.

The fact that two other
Afghanicenus species
were described from the region (only
A . aulicus
is marked on the map, since we focus on the Pakistani species in this paper) may raise some doubts as to their validity, especially considering such scant type material. It can, however, probably be explained by the topography of the region (highly mountainous area), which certainly intensified speciation processes of the local fauna. A similar distribution pattern in the neighbouring region was found in another cerambycid genus,
Turanium Baeckmann, 1922
( Cerambycinae : Callidiini ), in the mountains of Kyrgyzstan (
). In summary, geographical considerations, in addition to certain taxonomic reservations, only strengthen the need for a thorough revision of the type material in the genus
Afghanicenus
.
